Americans are apt to quarrel, but one thing we never, ever debate is whether we’d be better off with a king.

In Taunton, angst over defense cuts

The Pentagon’s request to cut $334 million from a contract with General Dynamics threatens hundreds of jobs, and has left Taunton feeling helpless.

LED streetlights a glaring concern

A multimillion-dollar project will replace Boston's roughly 60,000 electric streetlights with more efficient fixtures, but critics say they are too bright.
Opinion | Scot Lehigh

Time to end the limitation of statues

Four Massachusetts sons became president, yet none has a statue in Boston in open view, though the city features likenesses of plenty of other luminaries.

Maine islands wooing new residents

A $3 million initiative is using affordable housing to bolster year-round island communities, which have dwindled from about 300 to 15 over the past century.

Arts & Entertainment

Boston Pops retrospective

Formed in 1881 by Boston Symphony Orchestra founder Henry Lee Higginson, the Boston Pops performances were intended to be performed in the summer and were to be "concerts of a lighter kind of music," according to the BSO.
